149743357.review: A solid conclusion to the Five Nights at Freddy's series. Another shakeup to the classic Fnaf formula, but be warned that this game is heavily audio-dependent and Scott records his audio by trying to register movement in Idaho from his recording booth in Texas. Which is to say that you'll be wanting your audio on maximum, ensure your headphones aren't dying, and you'll still be squinting your ears. Despite that, it's a fun challenge and narratively brings one final close to Fnaf.

149741391.review:
FNAF 4: A Masterfully Crafted and Terrifying Gaming Experience

Introduction:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4 (FNAF 4) has achieved tremendous success in the gaming industry, primarily due to its unique blend of intelligent game design and terrifying atmospheric elements. As a graduate student, I appreciate the intricacies of this game and the way it captivates players with its immersive storyline, strategic gameplay, and spine-chilling horror. In this essay, I will delve into the reasons why FNAF 4 stands out as an excellent but terrifying game.

Paragraph 1: Complex Narrative Structure
The storytelling in FNAF 4 is remarkably intricate, diving further into the eerie events surrounding the Freddy Fazbear's Pizza franchise. The game expands on its predecessor's lore, focusing on a child's vivid nightmares while implementing psychological twists and turns that keep players engaged throughout the game.

Paragraph 2: Immersive and Atmospheric Design
Through its atmospheric design, FNAF 4 accomplishes an unparalleled level of immersion. The detailed graphics, sound effects, and clever use of lighting create an ominous ambiance that continuously keeps players on edge. This element of the game contributes significantly to the overall scare factor.

Paragraph 3: Suspenseful and Strategic Gameplay
FNAF 4 compels players with its strategic gameplay that requires intelligent decision-making and impeccable timing. This aspect engages the players' critical thinking skills and tests their ability to adapt under stress, further enhancing the overall experience.

Paragraph 4: Dynamic and Reactive Animatronics
The animatronics in FNAF 4 possess dynamic behaviors, making each encounter unpredictable and exponentially more terrifying. Their cleverly designed artificial intelligence challenges players to anticipate their movements, creating an intense sense of fear as they try to survive the night.

Paragraph 5: Strategic Audio Cues and Jumpscares
An integral part of FNAF 4's scare tactics lies within the strategic utilization of audio cues and jumpscares. The deliberate timing and placement of these elements heighten the suspense and deliver unforgettable moments of pure terror.

Paragraph 6: Psychological Horror Elements
Beyond its jump scares, FNAF 4 delves into the realm of psychological horror. The game intricately crafts an unsettling atmosphere that often leaves players lingering on the edge of their seats, exploring deeper themes of fear and vulnerability.

Paragraph 7: Engaging Player Experience
FNAF 4 offers an incredibly engaging experience that invites players to explore its secrets and uncover the hidden layers of its narrative. The game keeps players invested by providing a sense of agency while maintaining a balance between challenge and reward.

Paragraph 8: Replay Value and Exploration
The game's replay value and the freedom it grants players to explore multiple strategies enhance its entertainment factor. This encourages graduate-level students, like myself, to appreciate and analyze the game mechanics, fostering a deeper appreciation for its design philosophy.

Paragraph 9: Community Engagement and Analysis
FNAF 4 has cultivated an active and analytical community that seeks to unravel its mysteries and share their experiences. This online discourse fosters a sense of intellectual engagement, allowing graduate students to discuss and appreciate the game's intricacies.

Paragraph 10: Cultural Impact and Legacy
FNAF 4 has had a significant impact on popular culture, inspiring countless fan theories, analysis videos, and creative expressions. This cultural significance reveals the enduring legacy and the profound impact this game has made within the gaming community.

Conclusion:
With its intelligent design choices, gripping gameplay, and bone-chilling horror elements, FNAF 4 stands as an exceptional and terrifying gaming experience. As a graduate student, I find myself captivated by the narrative complexity, strategic gameplay, and atmospheric design that make this game a masterful blend of intelligence and horror. FNAF 4 has left an indelible mark on both the gaming industry and the hearts of players around the world.

149733680.review: No pensaba hacerle una review a ningún FNAF, no por nada, sino porque simplemente me los estaba rejugando con la intención de recordar los juegos, pero este me ha sorprendido gratamente. Sí, todos sabemos que los jumpscares es la forma de terror más básica y penosa que puede haber, no hace falta repetirlo hasta la saciedad. Sin embargo, creo que este juego es cruel. Para empezar, los diseños de los animatrónicos están muy bien logrados, realmente son productos sacados de una pesadilla que, después de todo, es de lo que va el juego. Pretenden hacerte sentir como cuando de niño tenías pesadillas sobre monstruos o simplemente te imaginabas que había algo en la puerta que vendria a por ti, y lo consiguen a la perfección. El sonido es extremadamente importante, es algo a lo que cuesta acostumbrarse pero no me parece una mala mecánica, aunque sí es cierto que es una putada para gente con problemas de audición. El caso es que se juega con el ajustamiento de sonido inicial tanto para ayudarte a recibir información del juego como para asustarte. En general, ha sido una experiencia bastante buena y creo que es uno de los FNAF que más "miedo" da.

148414210.review:
I figured making an actual review instead of a joke one could be nice.
This game is, in my opinion, the best in the whole franchise. Not only is the gameplay loop as enticing as ever, this game presents the most challenges yet at a whopping 8 nights as well as a customizable one with many challenges at your disposal, not to mention the slightly harder halloween dlc (Free!).

The character design (Important on a horror game) are a bit overkill, but are quite effective given the setting and fit really well given the proposed scenario of a kid having nightmares.

The drawback is its overreliance on sound. While the usage of sound queues to gain information is at its best on this game, it makes it hard for any hearing impaired to play, and makes the jumpscare aspect a bit cheap since it forces you into paying attention to quiet sound queues. One gets used to it relatively quicky however, and it becomes more than bearable.

Overall a really solid game that is worth its prize - RNG is not a deal-breaker, atmosphere and design is great, gameplay loop is fun and content is plentiful for the cost (And especially when compared to the previous, or even later entries)

Immersive Atmosphere: FNAF 4 excels in creating a tense and immersive atmosphere. The game's use of sound and darkness truly makes you feel like you're trapped in a creepy, dimly lit bedroom, with the lurking animatronic characters just around the corner. The game's ambiance is perfect for a horror game, and it's a significant factor in what makes it so enjoyable.

Challenging Gameplay: FNAF 4 offers a challenging and unique gameplay experience. Unlike the previous games in the series, this installment focuses on fending off animatronics in a more defensive manner, using sound and timing to survive the night. The increased difficulty adds to the adrenaline rush and the satisfaction of successfully warding off the animatronics.

Intriguing Storytelling: The FNAF series has always been known for its cryptic and mysterious lore, and FNAF 4 is no exception. The game provides more pieces to the puzzle of the overarching narrative, encouraging players to dive deeper into the lore and theories surrounding the game. The story elements can be quite intriguing and can leave players eager to uncover more secrets.

Jump Scares: FNAF 4 is renowned for its well-executed jump scares. The game keeps you on edge, making you anticipate the unexpected, which creates a thrilling and heart-pounding experience. The fear factor and surprise element are vital to the game's success in delivering genuine horror.

Nostalgia and Fandom: If you're a fan of the FNAF series, FNAF 4 is a satisfying addition to the franchise. It continues to build on the established characters and lore, providing a sense of nostalgia for long-time players. The game also connects with the FNAF fandom, offering more content for fans to explore and discuss.

146938074.review:
A problem that fnaf’s sequels have is that they never seem to live up to the original, from 2 and 3’s derivative and static game mechanics, to how 5 and 6 took fnaf’s atmosphere / story in a questionable direction, and we don’t talk about fnaf after 2017. But fnaf 4 stands out among the sequel for meeting the original in quality, if not surpassing it. It takes fnaf into a new setting and a new audio based gameplay loop, while conserving the logic of a nightmare in its game mechanics. And it tells its story in a new way, via cutscenes that slowly build up tension throughout the game while keeping the mystery of fnaf intact.

PS.
This is not to say I don’t like fnaf 2, 3, 5 and 6. I still think they have good atmospheres, mechanics and stories, and I value them a lot for the nostalgia I feel towards them. I just can’t help but think of them as being rather flawed.

146660032.review:
Five Nights at Freddy's 4

Desarrollador: Scott Cawthon

Año de lanzamiento: 2015

Plataformas: PC, iOS, Android

Reseña:

Gráficos (7/10): Los gráficos de "Five Nights at Freddy's 4" mantienen el estilo característico de la serie, con una estética de baja fidelidad y una iluminación tenue que contribuyen a la atmósfera inquietante. Aunque son adecuados para el género de terror, la falta de variedad de entornos puede hacer que el juego parezca repetitivo en comparación con las entregas anteriores.

Sonido (9/10): El diseño de sonido sigue siendo uno de los puntos fuertes de la serie. Los efectos de sonido inquietantes, los susurros y los gritos de los animatrónicos crean una atmósfera aterradora que sumerge a los jugadores en la experiencia. La música de fondo agrega tensión y anticipación a medida que avanzan las noches.

Jugabilidad (8/10): "Five Nights at Freddy's 4" introduce cambios significativos en la mecánica de juego en comparación con las entregas anteriores. Los jugadores deben moverse dentro de una habitación y utilizar el sonido para atraer o repeler a los animatrónicos. Esta nueva dinámica agrega un elemento estratégico interesante, pero también puede resultar más confusa y frustrante para algunos jugadores.

Historia y Narrativa (7/10): La historia de este juego se adentra aún más en el pasado de la franquicia, explorando los eventos que llevaron a la creación de los animatrónicos. Sin embargo, la narrativa sigue siendo fragmentada y se presenta principalmente a través de pistas y eventos ocultos, lo que puede requerir un esfuerzo adicional por parte de los jugadores para comprenderla por completo.

Atmósfera (9/10): La atmósfera de "Five Nights at Freddy's 4" es intensamente aterradora. El juego logra crear una sensación de claustrofobia y paranoia, ya que los jugadores se sienten acechados constantemente por los animatrónicos en una habitación oscura. La sensación de vulnerabilidad es palpable y contribuye en gran medida al horror del juego.

Dificultad (8/10): Este juego es desafiante y requiere una comprensión profunda de los patrones de los animatrónicos y una gestión cuidadosa del sonido. La curva de dificultad puede resultar abrupta y puede llevar tiempo acostumbrarse a las nuevas mecánicas de juego.

En resumen, "Five Nights at Freddy's 4" ofrece una experiencia de terror intensa y desafiante, con una atmósfera inmersiva y un diseño de sonido excepcional. Aunque introduce cambios significativos en la jugabilidad y la narrativa, algunos jugadores pueden encontrarlos desconcertantes. Si eres fan de la serie y estás dispuesto a enfrentar una experiencia aterradora y diferente, este juego sigue siendo una elección sólida.

146260480.review:
Probably gonna' get a fair amount of hate for this, but who cares. I consider myself a fan of the fnaf series, in spite of its many blemishes. 1-3 were games that I enjoyed a lot in spite of their flaws and naturally I expected the 4th entry to maintain that momentum. Thing is, this game was actually crashed and burned my original plans of beating all the games way back when.

I'll preface this by saying that no, I didn't beat fnaf 4, because it has in my opinion the worst gameplay loop of the entire main series and it frustrates me to the point of not wanting to play anymore.

To speak of the things I enjoy: I love the style, I think the atmosphere is the best this series has to offer, the new additions to the lore are super intriguing and the art direction is immaculate.

My big problem stems from the removal of the camera system from the previous games. By completely moving away from visual queue's to advance the gameplay, fnaf 4 focuses on audio, except in my opinion, its not a very fun or intuitive system. The main point of the game in reality is perfect time management. You've got all forces coming at you at all times and its up to you how you go about dealing with them all. Now if you mess up at all, this game punishes you severely. However, the whole point is that there are constant audio stings to let you know what you should be focusing on, and they're even directional, allowing you to know exactly what is the closest. For the first three nights, the game is actually really easy. By night 4 however, your constant need to move due to the enemies increased speeds makes it super easy to lose track of what audio you're hearing is background and whats actually coming to kill you. Sure, this makes for a tense and incredibly stressful experience, but it also completely messed with my ability to figure out what the hell was going on. I had multiple occasions where I would be listening at a closed door, I hear what I think is the enemies footsteps leaving, only to realise when I die that what I heard was actually an enemy on the other side of the fucking room, yet it sounded right next to me instead. Things like this take a bunch of skill out of the game and just throw pure luck instead as I pray that the game won't throw too much at me at a single time lest I need to just give up and restart again.

All of the previous games I was able to beat with reasonable effort and I felt as if it was always fair. In this case, I legit researched the mechanics just to make the game easier and yet I still kept getting screwed by elements that felt out of my control. So, I've gotta' put it down. Sorry to the fans of this one, but the gameplay killed it for me.

A labyrinth with no exit. A maze with no prize. You don't even realize that you are trapped. Your lust of blood has driven you in endless circles. Chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near.

It's somehow out of reach.

But, you will never find them. None of you will.

This is where your story ends.

And to you, my brave volunteer, who somehow found this job listing not intended for you. Although, there was a way out planned for you, I have a feeling that's not what you want. I have a feeling that you are right where you want to be.

I am remaining as well. I am nearby.

This place will not be remembered and the memory of everything that started this, can finally begin to fade away. As the agony of every tragedy should.

And to you monsters trapped in the corridors. Be still. And give up your spirits.

They don't belong to you.

As for most of you, I believe there is peace and perhaps, warm, waiting for you after the smoke clears.

Although, for one of you, the darkest pit of Hell has opened to swallow you whole. So, don't keep the Devil waiting, friend.

My daughter, if you can hear me, I knew you would return as well. It's in your nature to protect the innocent. I'm sorry that on that day, the day you were shut out and left to die, no one was there to lift you up in their arms, the way you lifted others into yours.

And then, what became of you, I should have known, you wouldn't be content to disappear. Not my daughter. I couldn't save you then.

So, let me save you now. It's time to rest, for you, and for those you have carried in your arms...

This ends.

For all of us.

End communication.

142368781.review: there comes a time when i just have to throw my hands up and say I Cant Play This ! grasping the mechanics was not my issue, i did manage 3 of 5 nights, but a combination of factors make it so that this is the only horror thing i can recall abandoning in my adult life for being too scary. i genuinely feel nigh completely non-functional while in control of this thing, and considering the precision that im sure the later nights require, at some point i just have to admit i do not have the mental capacity to muscle thru this. that Intensity Of Reaction is ofc well worth applauding on its own, and the reason why i ultimately think of this fondly. i could see it being a bit Oversimplistic and not scaling super well to the later nights (u are just Doing The Same Thing Over And Over with less and less room for error), but there is deffo something to be said for how theres just No Fat On It Designwise, every single tool and state of the bedroom is in constant use. by nature this is also the entry that leans the most into Expressionism, the nightmare animatronics are some of my favorite designs in the series i just love that Embellished Child POV stuff, which prob has a lot to do with why i find this so scary in the first place. there is no swinging between empowerment and disempowerment here, its All Disempowerment All The Time, yet still puts an incredibly stressful amount of Gameplay Responsibility on me. altogether its Pretty Unbearable, and also a weird Intended Conclusion for the series what with all the dream stuff? a less satisfying finale then fnaf3 for sure. but by far the most vivid Textural Experience of any of these for me, i gotta give it high marks even without seeing it thru. crying child kinnie era

Es triste que un juego tan bueno haya tenido tremendo descuido en la noche más importante de todas...

By far, the most terrifying game in the series, and for that and other reasons, FNaF4 is my personal favorite of the franchise
The gameplay is heart-pounding and truly a standout in horror, fully taking advantage of darkness, injecting so much fear into the player, never allowing them to feel safe, yet forcing them to be brave if they want to survive

137780472.review:
After beating nights 1 through to 8, I can't believe I've been ignoring this game for such a large portion of my (admittedly still ongoing) FNaF phase. Despite having watched playthroughs and even played it to a smaller degree when I was a kid, coming back to it years later and really immersing myself into the game for the first time in ages hit so differently. 

If you're looking to play this game, I highly recommend getting at least a decent set of earphones or headphones, and making sure external sounds are at a minimum. Being able to hear and recognise the breathing sounds, as well as the direction some footsteps are going, is essential to your survival, no matter the night.
 
In terms of volume, I personally recommend keeping it at a level where you can confidently make out the footsteps, which are notably more subtle than the breathing. Of course, having it higher will allow an easier recognition of sound cues, but it comes at the expense of having your eardrums blown in when you accidentally mess up and flash Bonnie in the face.

Gameplay wise, I found myself really enjoying the flow of it. It's simple, yet it keeps you busy at all times, especially in the later nights. Whether it's running to a door to listen for Bonnie or Chica, flashing the bed to keep Freddy at bay, listening to which side Foxy is running to, or tracking Fredbear's or Nightmare's distant footsteps, as long as you're familiar with the mechanics and know how to deal with each threat appropriately, it's always go-time until the alarm clock beeps at 6 AM. No limited power to worry about, no music box requiring your attention every three seconds, and no situations where RNGesus decides to throw you an unavoidable combination of attacks. It's just you, your flashlight, and those rabid anthropomorphic robots roaming the halls.

Ultimately, it went from being one of my most forgotten entries in the franchise, to one of my absolute favourites. It's tense, it's nerve-wracking, and it actually made me jump on numerous occasions. If you're weak-hearted and can't handle sudden Olympics height jumps in decibels in your ears, please don't play this game. If you can, however, I highly recommend giving this game a try, and if you're ever having trouble with any of the nights, I also highly recommend checking out Ambience's 'FNaF Academy' videos. I could not have gone as far as I did without them.

Good luck, and don't let the Freddles bite!

137518189.review:
[h1]Review:[/h1]

[b]Story:[/b]
I don't understand the story, I guess it's [spoiler]a nightmare after the crying kid in the minigames gets his head bit,[/spoiler]but I can't really be sure.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Easily the best in the series, because it's the scariest. Having to listen in and actually pay attention to what's going on makes it already more horrifying, not like you didn't have to do that before, but this is dialed up a few notches.
The fact that the game is mostly in darkness, and the only thing allowing you to see can easily get you killed makes it way more horrifying, not knowing what you will see when you click CTRL. 
The character mechanics are pretty good: 
Freddy isn't a big deal for the first few nights unless you forget he's there, but he is an actual issue after Night 5. Basically he sends mini freddies, or freddles, to your bed, and you have to flash them with your light to make them go away, if you don't, you die.
Bonnie and Chica come from the left and right hall, having to listen in for breathing and close doors to keep them out, if you don't they get in, and you die.
Foxy is always an issue. He runs from right to left hall trying to get in your room, however when he does he runs to the closet, and you have to shut the door to push him back from charging in. He's annoying to deal with, however it is possible to keep him out of your room.
Fredbear and Nightmare are all the animatronics at once. I haven't fought Nightmare yet, at the time of writing this, but once you understand how they work, only making a mistake will get you killed.
In fact, that becomes kind of an issue. Once you know how every character works, mistakes are really the only way to kill you, sometimes you don't even need headphones. However that's the only real issue.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
Might not be best story wise, but obviously the best FNAF gameplay wise.
9/10 FNAF game.

137446689.review:
(This review contains spoilers, in case you still haven't played this nearly-8-year-old game)

In this entry to the series, FNAF tries its hand at the "main character is trapped in their personal hell because they did something bad" trope, only to fall flat on its ass due to the needlessly cryptic execution of its story.

It's like having a really good burger with a really terrible patty.

While FNAF 4 is (in my opinion) the best entry in the series in terms of gameplay, character design, atmosphere and sound design, the story (or rather lack thereof) completely ruins the experience. To those of you who only play these games for the story, did you think FNAF 3 was a perfect conclusion to the series? Yes? Well then get ready to be disappointed, as this game, originally meant as the "final chapter," completely destroys the franchise with an infamously vague storyline that to this day nobody can truly agree on. This is the game that started the downward spiral of the FNAF series and its adamant refusal to tell a straightforward story for once.

Who are we actually playing as? Are we Mike Schmidt from the first game, suffering PTSD-induced nightmares thanks to slowly remembering that one time we killed our younger brother on his birthday? Are we actually the younger brother himself, trapped in a coma-induced nightmare as we slowly die? Are those 2 characters actually the same person? Are we actually neither of these people? Are the nightmare animatronics actually real, and we are trapped in an underground facility with them, being experimented on? How do Plushtrap and Nightmare BB fit into all of this? Who is Nightmare and what does he represent? Is he death itself? Or the ghostly spirit of the crying child seen in the minigames intent on having his revenge? When is this set in the timeline? Is Golden Freddy actually Fredbear, or are they separate entities entirely? What did the crying child see that made him so terrified of the animatronics? Did he witness a springlock failure? Did he witness the missing children incident? Who (or what) is the Fredbear plush, and why is he everywhere, even inside sewers and flowers as he watches us? Why does he sometimes have eyes that stare at us and sometimes have no eyes? Why is the tiny Toy chica missing her beak, and why was this such an important detail to the plot that Scott Cawthon himself had to make an entire teaser image on his website to point it out for the theorists in his fanbase?

Whereas in the previous 3 games these questions would've been shown and explained in a way that was mysterious yet easy-to-follow and understandable, FNAF 4 completely gives up trying to explain why these things are happening and instead relies on vague/cryptic easter eggs and the expectation that we'll just somehow understand it. Apparently Nightmare and Shadow Freddy are the same character, but we only know this because of something in the game's DECOMPILED SOURCE CODE, which your average player probably wouldn't see. I don't think I'm being unreasonable by saying that this is a very terrible way to tell your story.

Scott Cawthon has gone on record saying that the future games in the series (mainly Sister Location) were made to clarify FNAF 4's plot, but they did the opposite by doubling down and introducing a truckload of more plot elements to keep track of. All he had to do was release a patch that added a cutscene or 2 and changed the minigame dialogue to be less cryptic and we would've been fine, but instead of that we now have to add Funtime animatronics, Remnant/Agony, the Afton family, "illusion discs," multiple souls sharing the same animatronic, and the possibility that the nightmares were physically real-

Despite my problems with the game's story, this is by far the best one in terms of everything else. Scott wanted to make another entry in the series that was really scary again, and I for one think he nailed it. The character designs are monstrous, the emphasis on listening coupled with the intentionally quieter audio makes the jumpscares way more impacting (and loud!) than ever before, the ambience is pitch-perfect (Scott as always has really refined taste in sound choices), this game has by far the best main menu screen in the series, etc. As good as the game is, though, it becomes harder and harder to enjoy it when you're unaware of why anything is even happening in the first place. Like, sure I'm enjoying the game, but am I REALLY enjoying it when I'm missing out on crucial information and context behind why I'm in this bedroom in the first place?

I give this game a 7/10, 1 point for every year I've spent trying to puzzle over this game's impossible-to-understand plot. While I recommend this game for those who want a scarier FNAF game with a great aesthetic and sound design, if you're looking for a good story, there are way better alternatives to this. You're just going to get a headache, and the later games don't help like Scott claims they do.

-If you're looking for a game that tackles themes of loss, grief, death and familial tragedy (similar to the minigames in FNAF 4) I'd recommend playing OMORI.

-If you're looking for a game where you're trapped in a bedroom and have to deal with nightmarish abominations while slowly unraveling a vague (yet actually understandable, unlike FNAF 4) story, I'd recommend playing Silent Hill 4 (interestingly enough it's also the 4th game in that series too).

(There's also no shortage of other indie games that try their hand at doing this kind of story to varying degrees of success.)

Also, no custom night? Seriously?

135358097.review: Best one by far.First, it is genuinely scary. Having to listen really creates such a tense atmosphere. You also never really know for sure if you're safe.it has suprisingly really fun game play. It fits the fnaf formula by having you monitor animationics in a game play loop, but its so unique. usually in these games, beating the hardest mode isn't fun, only being something you do for completion. In this game i get genuine enjoyment out of nightmare mode and the other hard modes. I think the main reason is its not just one game play loop you do in a night, its 3. First theres how you play before foxy gets in, then after foxy's in the closet, then when Fredbear/nightmare come in. This gives the game a lot of variety in a single night, something no other games in the series have.The lore is also great in this entry while its not as good as games like 3, sister location, and FFPS, its still great. the minigames are genuinely scary, the ambience is creepy, contents are unnerving, and jumpscares are alright. It really makes you empathise with this scared child. The endings also are all great. The bite fo 83, while memed to death, is amazing. They way everything stops after the chomp is perfect. the one after night 6 (I dont know what to call it) is great. It has a good ballence of telling a lot while also leaving stuff up to interpretation. the box, despite how frustrating it is, I kinda like it. Although it will likely never be found out what it means, it will always be fascinating to theorise about. I also really like how you can fiddle with the locks for some reason.The jumpscares are also the 2nd best in the series, only beaten by sister location amazing jump scares. I guess I shouldn't be too impressed considering much of the competition is moving pngs and animatronics calmly walking in front of you, but they still look and function great.The extras menu is also so cool. it shows so much: the animatronic, jumpscares, fun with plushtrap minigame and a reskin, a making of foxy and freddbear, challenges, and he greatest of them all: cheats. The inclusion of cheats is such a cool addition. The map especially is so cool, it truelly disects the game, showing you how it works. Just please get it. Watching someone else play it does not give it justice.

Jambaven then requested for his crew to be hired, which Mr. Ateez agreed too. Now all together the party was questioned by a small goblin named Tinsil who asked them to play a game called “Temptaions”, he brought them to a room where a man named Cepit Viper told them the rules. Pay 50 gold and then spin the wheel on the wall, depending on where you land you can either get a prize or a penalty. Letting temptation take control the crew basically threw all there money at the wheel hoping for prizes. Jambaven the lucky bear gained two magical items while Lumpy gained eternal nightmares and Tommy gained Butterfly wings. Where the first game really rides on its novelty, this game is legitimately spooky.  It leans on the strengths of the original, adding new elements at a good rate.  It is a bit scummy that the game requires you to listen, incentivizing increasing volume to incredible decibels and then throws jumpscares in to blow out your ears.

But the way sound can be used to determine so much about the state of the game is a really beautiful thing.  Sitting and listening in darkness and then running strategically between the doors becomes so fun, even when the game's simple survival pattern is known.

130116501.review:
Close the door. Nightmare Bonnie is there. Crying Child would do that. Check the Closet too. Nightmare Foxy would mini-jumpscare you. If that happens, close the closet! If Nightmare Chica is at the right door, close the right door! Oh, and don't forget to check the bed. Freddles will be there and if 3 Freddles stay there for too long, Nightmare Freddy will form, killing you. Crying Child knows that and he is ready to do Night 1. What do you do? Go back.

If this happened to you, you are basically doomed. If you have not purchased a code for "Night 1", you will be stuck in this loop. Nightmare Chica is ready to spawn and sic the Jack-O-Lantern on you. Nightmare Foxy is waiting to jumble you. Nightmare Freddles will charge to get to you first. How do you fix this?

Back to top

Night 2

If Nightmare Chica kills you and the moment you die, you are returned to the couch. You do not respawn and the same thing will happen again. If Nightmare Freddy kills you, you go back to the couch. But because the cube goes to the afterlife, Freddy will be waiting for you.

This time, close the door and check the Bed. Nightmare Foxy will be there, Nightmare Chica will be in the Closet, Nightmare Freddy will be on the Bed and you will be back on the couch.

If you want to escape Nightmare Bonnie, there are two places to check. The door under the toy box is the first place you should check. If you know where this door is, read the next post on the forum. Also, Nightmare Bonnie will be waiting for you.

But if you use the "return to couch" setting, the doors will open.

Back to top

Night 3

Once you have completed the Nightmare Nightmare Moon stage, you will be placed on the couch. Nightmare Chica is not ready to spawn and the Bonnie Prank must be complete. Once that happens, the couch disappears and you are back on the shelf.

To add to the confusion, the door in the corner of the Closet will open and Nightmare Chica will be in the Closet. She will be stuck behind the door. If you use the cheat to close that door, Nightmare Chica will not spawn. That door may only open once a day so you can only use it for 2 hours, after which it will close for good.

The house is now empty.

Back to top

Night 4

When you wake up in the bed, this is what will happen. Night 1 happens again, but you won't get any injuries this time. Since you died and returned to the couch, the door under the bed will be closed and the jack-o-lantern won't spawn.

Night 2 happens once again, but this time, Nightmare Chica will not take you. Nightmare Bonnie will again finish his job and kill you. You will respawn on the couch.

Night 3 happens again and this time, Nightmare Bonnie will kill you. You won't die this time but you will be injured and the door in the corner will be open. Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the "return to couch" setting, the door in the corner will open and Nightmare Bonnie will be waiting for you.

Night 4 happens once again and this time, Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Foxy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddles will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. You will die once again and the door in the corner will be open. Nightmare Bonnie will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the "return to couch" setting, the door in the corner will open and Bonnie will be waiting for you.

To fix this glitch, go to the Dreamopolis minigame. All the traps are not active yet. The problem will fix itself.

Back to top

Night 5

The Bed will not appear, even though Nightmare Freddy will be sleeping in the crib. Night 1 will repeat and you will die and respawn on the couch.

If you run the cheat to lock the bed, Night 1 will not happen and you can continue to use the couch glitch.

Back to top

Night 6

Night 3 repeats and you will die and respawn on the couch.

Night 4 is pretty much the same as the other nights. Nightmare Chica will not spawn and Nightmare Foxy will not finish his job and kill you. This time, you will die and respawn on the couch.

Night 5 repeats and this time, the door in the corner will be open. Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the cheat to lock the bed, this time the door will close. Nightmare Bonnie will not appear. This is why you only get the unlockable jack-o-lantern in the other cases.

Night 6 repeats and this time, the door in the corner will be closed. Nightmare Foxy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddles will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Bonnie will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the "return to couch" setting, the door in the corner will open and Bonnie will be waiting for you.

To fix this glitch, you have to get the chest from the Dreamopolis minigame and put it somewhere far enough from the couch where the bed does not show up. If you have Bonnie's spider staff, you can now use it to go in the opposite direction from where the bed shows up.
Back to top

Night 7

Night 4 repeats and you will die and respawn on the couch.

Night 5 repeats and this time, the door in the corner will be open. Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Bonnie will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddles will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Foxy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. You will die and respawn on the couch.

Night 6 repeats and this time, the door in the corner will be closed. Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Foxy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddles will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Bonnie will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the "return to couch" setting, the door in the corner will open and Bonnie will be waiting for you.

To fix this glitch, put the chest near the safe room on the 2nd floor. This will cause Nightmare Chica to not spawn in the crib and the chest will be put somewhere else.

Back to top

Night 8

Night 3 is the same as the other nights, except you can not use the couch glitch.

Night 4 repeats and this time, the door in the corner will be open. Nightmare Chica will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Bonnie will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Freddles will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. Nightmare Foxy will kill you and there will be no jack-o-lantern. If you use the "return to couch" setting, the door in the corner will open and Bonnie will be waiting for you.

To fix this glitch, this time, lock the couch before you kill the guard to avoid them seeing you.

All thanks and credits to InferKit for generating the text.

128191997.review:
"Hello, hello? Uh, I wanted to record a message for you to help you get settled in on your first night. Um, I actually worked in that office before you. I'm finishing up my last week now, as a matter of fact. So, I know it can be a bit overwhelming, but I'm here to tell you there's nothing to worry about. Uh, you'll do fine. So, let's just focus on getting you through your first week. Okay?

Uh, let's see, first there's an introductory greeting from the company that I'm supposed to read. Uh, it's kind of a legal thing, you know. Um, "Welcome to Freddy Fazbear's Pizza. A magical place for kids and grown-ups alike, where fantasy and fun come to life. Fazbear Entertainment is not responsible for damage to property or person. Upon discovering that damage or death has occurred, a missing person report will be filed within 90 days, or as soon property and premises have been thoroughly cleaned and bleached, and the carpets have been replaced."

Blah blah blah, now that might sound bad, I know, but there's really nothing to worry about. Uh, the animatronic characters here do get a bit quirky at night, but do I blame them? No. If I were forced to sing those same stupid songs for twenty years and I never got a bath? I'd probably be a bit irritable at night too. So, remember, these characters hold a special place in the hearts of children and we need to show them a little respect, right? Okay.

So, just be aware, the characters do tend to wander a bit. Uh, they're left in some kind of free roaming mode at night. Uh...Something about their servos locking up if they get turned off for too long. Uh, they used to be allowed to walk around during the day too. But then there was The Bite of '87. Yeah. I-It's amazing that the human body can live without the frontal lobe, you know? Uh, now concerning your safety, the only real risk to you as a night watchman here, if any, is the fact that these characters, uh, if they happen to see you after hours probably won't recognize you as a person. They'll p-most likely see you as a metal endoskeleton without its costume on. Now since that's against the rules here at Freddy Fazbear's Pizza, they'll probably try to...forcefully stuff you inside a Freddy Fazbear suit. Um, now, that wouldn't be so bad if the suits themselves weren't filled with crossbeams, wires, and animatronic devices, especially around the facial area. So, you could imagine how having your head forcefully pressed inside one of those could cause a bit of discomfort...and death. Uh, the only parts of you that would likely see the light of day again would be your eyeballs and teeth when they pop out the front of the mask, heh.

Y-Yeah, they don't tell you these things when you sign up. But hey, first day should be a breeze. I'll chat with you tomorrow. Uh, check those cameras, and remember to close the doors only if absolutely necessary. Gotta conserve power. Alright, good night."

125674585.review: To be honest, if there was any game that I thought under performed in Scott's games, it had to be this one. Now, the features and story of the game are fine, and I like the visuals, mechanics, and all the Halloween DLC. THAT is not why I am saying  it isn't as good. It's the sound cues. See, in FNAF 4 you need to be able to hear EVERYTHING. From footsteps, to breathing, to the freddles. And that wouldn't be so bad. Except that these sound cues are much lower than the ambiance or the wind itself, and Scott only amped up one sound: The Jumpscares. SO even if your headphones are at only 20, your gonna hear a sound as if it were at 70 or something, and for other sounds its different. It especially makes no sense to me why scott made them louder in game than in the extras menu unlike FNAF 3, in which they are the same sound quality. I just wish that Scott would have focused more on not making it so anticipatingly scary, and focused more on something like he did for UCN, where the sounds are a bit louder. It just makes the game near unplayable, because Nightmare is the only animatronic that is more lenient with the jumpscares at a volume of 50-70, where the others are wildly loud. Overall, i think the sounds could be redone is all.

124482870.review:
arguably the worst game in the series (unless you like getting your ears destroyed by unnecessarily loud screaming). the animatronic designs are good (easily the scariest in the series), and the gameplay is good in theory but the audio mechanic just ruins it.
you have to listen for an audio cue, if you don't hear the audio then you're good to shine your flashlight in the hallways. if you do hear the audio cue then you have to shut the door and not shine your flashlight in the hallway or you'll be jumpscared. sounds simple enough, right?
well here's the thing: the audio cue is so quiet it makes librarians seem like they're screaming. you [i]have[/i] to have the volume [i]super[/i] high, and with headphones on, to hear the audio cue. normally that'd be somewhat ok, [i][b]if the jumpscare audio didn't end up becoming loud enough to be heard on the goddamn moon because of it[/b][/i]
the jumpscare audio should have had it's own volume setting

123171838.review: Ok, I have to say that this might not only be the scariest FNAF GAME ever, but this might be one of the scariest GAMES ever. FNAF 4 does It's horror in a way I haven't seen any other game replicate. Just playing this game is so stressful because of what will happen once they get you. Audio is this games core mechanic and boy howdy does it use that SUPER effectively. The sound that is key to survival is so quiet that you would have to turn your volume all the way up, forcing you out of your comfort zone. This makes the already super loud jumpscares even louder than they already were, leading to even more stress, and then leading to even more mistakes being made that triggers that jumpscare that you're trying so desperately to NEVER see again because it's fucking scary. FNAF usually gets so much shit for "relying on jumpscares" when in actuality the tension is what leads to the jumpscare being so effective. This is a prime example of that and it just shatters the whole "jumpscare fest" mindset a lot of people who hate this series seem to adapt. This shows the horror genius that is Scott Cawthon and what hes capable of bringing to the table.

120317228.review:
I'd like to say a very happy 8th anniversary for FNaF. This game series really means a lot to me, and I cannot thank Scott Cawthon enough for making a lot of my childhood memories. . . With all that being said after playing through most of this game in a FNaF marathon I'm doing in celebration of the anniversary, I can safely say this is my least favorite game in the series so far. Don't get me wrong, it's pretty damn good, but personally this is my least favorite in the series for a number of reasons. 
For one, I get that this game is meant to be loud, but I had to turn my headphones up to max volume in order to hear some of the stuff in this game, and even then the ambiance largely drowns out the important noises. This wouldn't be so bad if it weren't for the fact that any time you get jumpscared (which will happen very often) it's louder than a damn heavy metal concert. Luckily the jumpscares themselves are pretty short, so you don't get hit too bad by the noise, but it's still somewhat painful. Foxy's also seems louder than all the others for some reason, which I'm not a fan of. 
But then there's probably my biggest issue with the game. it doesn't really make itself very clear as to how the mechanics should work. I've been a FNaF fan since 2014, and I still had absolutely no idea what I was doing when I first jumped into this game, despite having seen dozens of videos surrounding it. The breathing and walking sounds are too subtle, even in just the first 4 nights. But then, there's night 5 which I kind of despise. Nightmare Fredbear's mechanics aren't clear enough. I even read the  "Fnafapedia wikia" about him, and I still couldn't get an easy grasp on his mechanics. Now, usually when he laughs he's either in the closet or the bed, but if he laughs AND runs, then he's trying to trick you. That sounds fine, but then you remember the sounds the characters make being too quiet. If that wasn't bad enough, sometimes he just doesn't follow his own rules. I had a number of friends who are also FNaF veterans watch me play, and they were just as confused as I was. It was pretty frustrating, and Nightmare is basically that but worse. Luckily, he doesn't last as long as Fredbear.

The things that I did like about the game are the fact that it's definitely the most challenging FNaF game. I know I kind of just complained about things making it unnecessarily hard, but let me explain. FNaF by that point had only really had difficult final nights. Nights 5 - 7 were usually the only ones that really were super difficult, with the first few nights being relatively easy. Heck, FNaF 3 doesn't even have an animatronic on the first night, and honestly Nightmare Mode is the only super challenging part of that game once you learn how to juggle springtrap. FNaF 1 & 2 don't suffer from this as much, but they still weren't all that challenging until their final few nights. This game meanwhile is easily more difficult than any of the others. With FNaF 1 & 2 you had to go out of your way to die on the first night, and as said previously you couldn't even die on the first night of FNaF 3, so having a game in the series with some serious challenge is certainly welcome, even if I think it might've gone a bit too far in that direction. 

Of course, the lore is always the most interesting part of this series, and FNaF 4 is certainly one of the most interesting parts of the series, especially with the mysterious box at the end. 

I think this game is really great. I think the mechanics themselves are pretty good, although they're very VERY hard to learn, thanks to the game's insane difficulty. (Especially when compared to the previous games, and even the games that came after.) I think this game is my least favorite from a pure gameplay perspective, but I understand why most people would disagree. It's got a unique level of challenge, provides important lore, and has some fun mechanics. My biggest gripe is really with the audio and some mechanics not being as intuitive as they could've been. This is a pretty darn good game, if a very frustrating one.

118925349.review:
I love the FNAF series, but I have never liked this game. Audio mechanics have always been a thing in the games (Freddy laughing when moving in FNAF 1, Balloon Boy saying hi when moving in FNAF 2, or vent sounds when Springtrap enters a vent in FNAF 3). However, I just don't like it being the main focus. FNAF is a series where the gameplay needs to be good to play the game, since the visuals, while good, are not good enough on it's own to get the game, and while the story is very interesting, you will still miss a lot even if you play the game, but I just can't hear the breathing for THE LIFE OF ME. Because of this I really don't recommend the game. However there are some things I appreciate about the game. The character designs, while not the most creative, are still good and effective at creating fear. Next it had some good things to change up gameplay, such as Night 5 replacing the main 4 animatronics with Nightmare Fredbear, Fun with Plushtrap, and the Halloween version of the game. Finally this game brought the story from an interesting story about a madman and his murders with knock off Chuck E Cheese to a truly complex narrative. I know some people think the story got stupid starting with this game, and while I agree to a degree, I overall think the games have a good story.

TL;DR-I appreciate what the game did for the series but wouldn't recommend it.

114430937.review:
The fourth installment of the Five Nights at Freddy's franchise is conceptually one of my favorites but in execution one of my least favorites.

The gameplay of 4 relies on breathing which is essentially the audio from 1 and 2 but heightened and needed to live a lot more, but more often than not in this game it gets drowned out by ambience.

The animatronics are all fine to deal with even Nightmare, but the one I can't stand is the Nightmare Cupcake, for some reason it can get into your room without you knowing and usually camps until 2 hours has passed and then kills you. I've never found the audio cue for it coming into the room nor it being by the door. And even if there was you have so much to deal with that you'll forget eventually and just die. 

I'd say if you want to try to play this be by guest. Get it on sale at the very least. 

5.2/10
